articles.headline: Embattled, Fund Shifts Cost of Suits to Investors
articles.snippet: If shareholders continue to wage legal battles against the fund and its manager, they risk getting far less back, because more of their money will be used to pay the fund company’s outside lawyers.
articles.abstract: If shareholders continue to wage legal battles against the fund and its manager, they risk getting far less back, because more of their money will be used to pay the fund company’s outside lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Reserve Primary Fund has presented its deeply frustrated shareholders with a stark choice.

articles.headline: Washington’s New Tack: Helping Home Buyers
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department is working on a plan to boost the housing market by subsidizing 30-year home mortgages with rates as low as 4.5 percent.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department is working on a plan to boost the housing market by subsidizing 30-year home mortgages with rates as low as 4.5 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After pouring vast amounts of money into financial institutions of almost every type, and having little to show for it, the Bush administration and the Federal Reserve are suddenly taking a new look at ordinary homeowners.

articles.headline: Many Children Lack Stability Long After Storm
articles.snippet: Young victims of Hurricane Katrina are behind in school and suffering from illness and mental health problems.
articles.abstract: Young victims of Hurricane Katrina are behind in school and suffering from illness and mental health problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Last January, at the age of 15, Jermaine Howard stopped going to school. Attendance seemed pointless: Jermaine, living with his father and brother in the evacuee trailer park known as Renaissance Village since Hurricane Katrina in 2005, had not managed to earn a single credit in more than two years.

articles.headline: Energy Goals a Moving Target for States
articles.snippet: States’ struggles to satisfy energy mandates offer lessons for the next administration.
articles.abstract: States’ struggles to satisfy energy mandates offer lessons for the next administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: In hopes of slowing global warming and creating “green jobs,” Congress and the incoming administration may soon impose a mandate that the nation get 10 or 15 percent of its electricity from renewable sources within a few years.
articles.byline: By Kate Galbraith and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Trump Sees Act of God in Recession
articles.snippet: Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit maintaining that the current financial crisis provides him with a good reason not to pay $40 million owed to Deutsche Bank.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit maintaining that the current financial crisis provides him with a good reason not to pay $40 million owed to Deutsche Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Guess who is complaining that condominiums in Donald Trump’s latest big project are ridiculously overpriced.

articles.headline: Hospitals Now a Theater in Mexico’s Drug War
articles.snippet: Mexico’s violent drug war is finding its way into the seeming sanctuary of the nation’s hospitals.
articles.abstract: Mexico’s violent drug war is finding its way into the seeming sanctuary of the nation’s hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico  The sedated patient, his bullet wounds still fresh from a shootout the night before, was lying on a gurney in the intensive care unit of a prestigious private hospital here late last month with intravenous fluids dripping into his arm. Suddenly, steel-faced gunmen barged in and filled him with even more bullets. This time, he was dead for sure.

articles.headline: H. M., an Unforgettable Amnesiac, Dies at 82
articles.snippet: Henry Gustav Molaison, or H.M., was recognized as the most important patient in the history of brain science.
articles.abstract: Henry Gustav Molaison, or H.M., was recognized as the most important patient in the history of brain science.
articles.lead_paragraph: He knew his name. That much he could remember.

articles.headline: Police Foiled Earlier Plot Against Mumbai
articles.snippet: In February, police disrupted a planned attack on Mumbai, breaking up a cell directed by the same two Pakistan-based groups suspected of recent attacks.
articles.abstract: In February, police disrupted a planned attack on Mumbai, breaking up a cell directed by the same two Pakistan-based groups suspected of recent attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  The Indian police foiled an attempt to destroy landmarks and wreak havoc in Mumbai early this year, breaking up a cell of Pakistani and Indian men who were directed by the same two Pakistan-based militant leaders they have accused of organizing last week’s devastating attacks here, the police said.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: U.S. Loses 533,000 Jobs in Biggest Drop Since 1974
articles.snippet: The government’s report of vast job losses in November puts increased pressure on Washington to act quickly on a stimulus package.
articles.abstract: The government’s report of vast job losses in November puts increased pressure on Washington to act quickly on a stimulus package.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Louis Uchitelle, Edmund L. Andrews and Stephen Labaton and written by Mr. Uchitelle.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle, Edmund L. Andrews and Stephen Labaton
